newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PAL strikers defy return-to-work order.
newsitem.headline: PAL strikers defy return-to-work order.

text.p: Philippine Airlines ground crew defied a return-to-work order by the labour department whose deadline expired at midnight on Friday, a union officer said on Saturday.
"We are still on strike," PAL Employees' Association officer Jun Limor told Reuters in a telephone interview.
The national carrier had earlier warned workers who did not return to work by Friday midnight that they would be sacked.

Limor said union officers and PAL managers were still talking at the Department of Labour and Employment office to find a solution to the strike which started on Wednesday evening over a new wage package.
Talks have been going on since Thursday afternoon.
PAL said eight international and 36 domestic flights were cancelled on Saturday. Strikers include those taking flight reservations and baggage and cargo handlers.
"(We) will continue maximising available manpower in order to mount as many international and domestic flights as possible," PAL said in a statement.
The workers are asking for a wage package worth 3.2 billion pesos ($121 million) over the next two years.
PAL has rejected the package and instead offered to sell employees PAL shares worth 477 million pesos at five pesos per share.
It is the third strike to hit financially troubled PAL in two years. The employees' association struck twice in 1994, the first stoppage lasting a day and the second nine days.
